choices.text: Upper trunk of brachial plexus involved

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Upper trunk of brachial plexus involved This statement is false because Klumpke's paralysis results from injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 nerve roots), not the upper trunk. The lower trunk provides innervation to the intrinsic muscles of the hand and some of the forearm muscles. Damage to this region can occur due to excessive traction on the arm during delivery or trauma, leading to the characteristic symptoms of Klumpke’s paralysis. The upper trunk, which includes C5 and C6 nerve roots, is involved in Erb’s palsy, a different condition. Incorrect Responses: (A) Claw hand deformity This statement is correct. Klumpke’s paralysis often results in a claw hand deformity due to paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. The flexors of the digits (innervated by the ulnar and median nerves) are unopposed by the extensor muscles, leading to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. (B) Intrinsic muscles of hand involved This statement is correct. The intrinsic muscles of the hand (lumbricals, interossei, thenar, and hypothenar muscles) are supplied by the C8 and T1 nerve roots via the ulnar and median nerves. Injury to these roots in Klumpke’s paralysis results in weakness or paralysis of these muscles, contributing to the claw hand deformity and impaired fine motor control. (C) Horner’s syndrome This statement is correct. In severe cases of Klumpke’s paralysis, involvement of the T1 root can extend to the sympathetic chain, leading to Horner’s syndrome. Symptoms include ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (loss of sweating) on the affected side of the face due to sympathetic dysfunction.

questions.text: Which among the following is a branch from the trunk of brachial plexus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nerve to subclavius The nerve to subclavius arises directly from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (formed by the union of the C5 and C6 roots). It innervates the subclavius muscle, which stabilizes the clavicle and protects the underlying neurovascular structures during shoulder movement. As it is a direct branch of the trunk, this option is correct. Incorrect Responses: (A) Suprascapular nerve The suprascapular nerve also originates from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6). It supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which are involved in shoulder abduction and external rotation. While the nerve to subclavius may be considered the primary branch associated with the trunk, the suprascapular nerve is equally valid as a branch. (B) Long thoracic nerve The long thoracic nerve arises directly from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5, C6, and C7), not the trunk. It innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is critical for scapular protraction and stabilization. Damage to this nerve can lead to a "winged scapula," but its origin excludes it as a correct answer. (C) Anterior thoracic nerve The term "anterior thoracic nerve" is often used interchangeably with the lateral and medial pectoral nerves, which arise from the cords of the brachial plexus (not the trunks). These nerves supply the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor muscles, ruling them out as correct answers.

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve arises from medial cord
Radial nerve arises from posterior cord
Post fixed plexus is formed by C4,5,6,7,8 T1

questions.text: The following is true of brachial plexus:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Radial nerve arises from the posterior cord The radial nerve is a terminal branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, which is derived from the posterior divisions of all three trunks (upper, middle, and lower). The radial nerve is responsible for motor innervation to the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm and sensory innervation to the posterior surface of the arm, forearm, and hand. Its origin from the posterior cord makes this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Cervical rib involves lateral cord This is incorrect because a cervical rib typically compresses the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 roots), not the lateral cord. The lower trunk contributes to the medial cord, not the lateral cord, so symptoms such as weakness or sensory loss are more likely to involve the ulnar nerve and parts of the median nerve derived from the medial cord. (B) Musculocutaneous nerve arises from medial cord The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord, not the medial cord, of the brachial plexus. It innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm (biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis) and provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the forearm. (D) Postfixed plexus is formed by C4,5,6,7,8 T1 This is incorrect because a postfixed brachial plexus is formed by C6, C7, C8, T1, and T2, not by C4. The usual configuration of the brachial plexus includes roots C5–T1. A prefixed plexus, by contrast, includes contributions from C4 and terminates at T1.

questions.text: Medial cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nerve to supraspinatus The nerve to supraspinatus, also known as the suprascapular nerve, arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, specifically from the roots of C5 and C6. It innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles and passes through the suprascapular notch. Since it originates from the upper trunk and not the medial cord, it is not related to the medial cord, making it the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (B) Ulnar nerve The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus, receiving contributions from C8 and T1 roots. It is one of the primary terminal branches of the medial cord, responsible for innervating several muscles of the forearm and hand and providing sensory input to the medial hand. (C) Medial cutaneous nerve of arm The medial cutaneous nerve of the arm (also called the medial brachial cutaneous nerve) arises directly from the medial cord of the brachial plexus. It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the medial side of the arm. (D) Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm The medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm (medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve) is another direct branch of the medial cord. It supplies sensory innervation to the skin of the medial forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not a branch of posterior cord of Brachial plexus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ulnar Nerve The ulnar nerve arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus, with contributions from the C8 and T1 nerve roots. It does not have any direct association with the posterior cord. The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand (except for those innervated by the median nerve) and provides sensory innervation to the medial side of the hand. Incorrect Responses: (A) Thoracodorsal Nerve The thoracodorsal nerve, also called the middle subscapular nerve, is a branch of the posterior cord. It innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is responsible for movements such as adduction, extension, and medial rotation of the arm. (B) Radial Nerve The radial nerve is the largest branch of the posterior cord and innervates all the extensor muscles of the arm, forearm, and hand, as well as providing sensory innervation to the posterior aspect of the arm and forearm. (D) Axillary Nerve The axillary nerve is another branch of the posterior cord. It innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the shoulder region.

questions.text: Fascia around nerve bundle of brachial plexus is derived from –(AllMS)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prevertebral Fascia The fascia surrounding the nerve bundle of the brachial plexus is derived from the prevertebral fascia. This deep fascia originates from the cervical region and envelops the muscles associated with the vertebral column, such as the scalene muscles. As the brachial plexus emerges from the neck through the interscalene space (between the anterior and middle scalene muscles), the prevertebral fascia extends laterally to form a sheath around the plexus. This sheath provides structural support and protection to the nerves as they pass into the axilla. Incorrect Options: (B) Pretracheal Fascia The pretracheal fascia is located anteriorly in the neck and encloses structures such as the trachea, esophagus, and thyroid gland. It does not extend posteriorly or laterally to surround the brachial plexus, making it unrelated to the fascia of the nerve bundle. (C) Investing Layer The investing layer of deep cervical fascia is the most superficial layer of deep fascia and encircles the neck, enclosing the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. While it contributes to enclosing some superficial structures, it does not form the sheath for the brachial plexus. (D) Superficial Cervical Fascia The superficial cervical fascia is a layer of connective tissue that lies just beneath the skin and contains structures such as the platysma muscle. It does not extend to deeper structures like the brachial plexus and therefore does not form its fascia.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is a branch from the trunk of brachial plexus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Suprascapular nerve The suprascapular nerve is a branch that arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. It provides motor innervation to the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which are involved in shoulder abduction and lateral rotation, respectively. The suprascapular nerve is one of the few branches that originate directly from the trunks of the brachial plexus, specifically the upper trunk. Incorrect Options: (B) Long Thoracic Nerve The long thoracic nerve does not arise from the trunks of the brachial plexus. It originates from the roots of the brachial plexus, specifically from C5, C6, and C7. This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which plays a key role in scapular protraction and upward rotation. (C) Dorsal Scapular Nerve The dorsal scapular nerve also arises from the roots of the brachial plexus, specifically from C5. It innervates the rhomboid muscles and the levator scapulae, helping in the elevation and retraction of the scapula. It is not a branch of the trunk. (D) Nerve to Subclavius (Nerve to S. Anterior) The nerve to subclavius arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus but is distinct from the suprascapular nerve. It innervates the subclavius muscle, which stabilizes the clavicle during movements of the shoulder girdle. However, it is not as commonly cited as the suprascapular nerve when discussing major trunk branches.

questions.text: Not a branch of posterior cord of Brachial plexus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Long thoracic nerve The long thoracic nerve is not a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It arises from the roots of the brachial plexus, specifically from the C5, C6, and C7 nerve roots. This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is essential for protracting the scapula and stabilizing it against the thoracic wall. Its anatomical origin and function are distinct from the posterior cord and its branches. Incorrect Options: (A) Axillary nerve The axillary nerve is a direct branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the deltoid region. As it originates from the posterior cord, this option is incorrect. (B) Thoracodorsal nerve The thoracodorsal nerve, also known as the middle subscapular nerve, is another branch of the posterior cord. It innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is responsible for adduction, extension, and medial rotation of the arm. Since it originates from the posterior cord, this option is incorrect. (C) Radial nerve The radial nerve is the largest branch of the posterior cord and supplies the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm, as well as sensory innervation to the posterior aspect of the arm and hand. Its origin from the posterior cord confirms that this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Largest branch of brachial plexus is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Radial nerve. The radial nerve is the largest branch of the brachial plexus. It arises from the posterior cord and is formed by contributions from the C5 to T1 nerve roots. The radial nerve is responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of the posterior arm and forearm, including the triceps brachii, brachioradialis, and extensor muscles of the forearm. It also provides sensory innervation to much of the posterior arm, forearm, and hand. Due to its wide distribution and extensive motor and sensory functions, the radial nerve is considered the largest branch of the brachial plexus. Evaluation of Each Option: A. Ulnar nerve Incorrect The ulnar nerve is an important branch of the brachial plexus but is not the largest. It arises from the medial cord and innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, as well as some forearm muscles. However, compared to the radial nerve, its distribution is smaller, making this option incorrect. B. Median nerve Incorrect The median nerve arises from both the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus and innervates most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some intrinsic muscles in the hand. While it has a significant distribution, it is not the largest branch of the brachial plexus in terms of size or functional reach, making this option incorrect. D. Axillary nerve Incorrect The axillary nerve is a smaller branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles. While important for shoulder movement, it is smaller in comparison to the radial nerve,

questions.text: All are infraclavicular branches of brachial plexus except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Long thoracic nerve. The long thoracic nerve arises from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5, C6, and C7), which are considered supraclavicular branches because they emerge from the neck region above the clavicle. In contrast, the infraclavicular branches of the brachial plexus originate below the clavicle. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in the protraction of the scapula. Since the long thoracic nerve is a root-level branch and not an infraclavicular branch, it is the correct answer to the question. Evaluation of Each Option: A. Ulnar nerve Incorrect The ulnar nerve is an infraclavicular branch of the brachial plexus. It originates from the medial cord and supplies the muscles of the forearm and hand, as well as providing sensory innervation to the ulnar side of the hand. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Axillary nerve Incorrect The axillary nerve is an infraclavicular branch of the brachial plexus. It arises from the posterior cord and innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, as well as providing sensory innervation to the skin over the shoulder. Therefore, this option is incorrect. D. Thoracodorsal nerve Incorrect The thoracodorsal nerve is also an infraclavicular branch of the brachial plexus, arising from the posterior cord. It innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in movements such as adduction, extension, and internal rotation of the arm.

questions.text: Policeman’s tip hand is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Erb's palsy. Policeman's tip hand is a characteristic deformity seen in Erb’s palsy, which results from an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6 nerve roots). This injury often occurs during birth (e.g., due to shoulder dystocia) or from trauma (e.g., a fall). The resultant nerve damage leads to weakness or paralysis in muscles innervated by C5 and C6 roots, including the deltoid, biceps, and brachialis muscles. As a result, the arm is held in an adducted, internally rotated position, with the forearm extended and pronated, which resembles the "tip" position of a policeman signaling "stop," hence the term "policeman's tip hand." Evaluation of Each Option: B. Klumpke’s paralysis Incorrect Klumpke’s paralysis results from injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1), often caused by excessive traction on the arm during delivery or trauma. This condition causes paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles, leading to a "claw hand" deformity rather than the policeman’s tip hand. It affects the small muscles of the hand but not the upper arm muscles in the way Erb's palsy does. C. Axillary nerve injury Incorrect An injury to the axillary nerve typically causes weakness or paralysis of the deltoid and teres minor muscles. However, it does not cause the characteristic position of the policeman's tip hand. Instead, there would be difficulty in shoulder abduction and a flattened shoulder contour due to deltoid weakness, making this option incorrect. D. None of the above Incorrect Since Erb’s palsy is the condition associated with policeman’s tip hand, option (A) is the correct answer,

Correct Answer (A) Teres minor. The posterior cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the teres minor muscle. The teres minor is a rotator cuff muscle that helps with lateral (external) rotation of the arm and stabilizes the glenohumeral joint. The posterior cord primarily supplies muscles of the shoulder and posterior arm through its branches, including the axillary and radial nerves. Evaluation of Each Option: B. Pectoralis minor Incorrect The pectoralis minor is innervated by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves, which arise from the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus, respectively. Since these nerves do not originate from the posterior cord, this option is incorrect. C. Coracobrachialis Incorrect The coracobrachialis is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. It is not supplied by the posterior cord, making this option incorrect. D. Long head of biceps Incorrect The long head of the biceps brachii is also innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve from the lateral cord. The posterior cord does not contribute to the innervation of the biceps brachii,

questions.text: Which of the following nerve carries fibres from all the roots of brachial plexus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Median nerve. The median nerve is the only nerve in the brachial plexus that carries fibers from all five roots (C5, C6, C7, C8, and T1). It is formed by the union of the lateral root from the lateral cord (which contains fibers from C5, C6, and C7) and the medial root from the medial cord (which contains fibers from C8 and T1). Therefore, the median nerve has contributions from every root of the brachial plexus, making it unique in this aspect. Incorrect Responses: A. Axillary nerve: The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, specifically carrying fibers from C5 and C6. It does not have contributions from all the roots of the brachial plexus, so it is not the correct answer. B. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve is formed from the medial cord of the brachial plexus, primarily carrying fibers from C8 and T1. It does not receive contributions from the C5, C6, or C7 roots, and thus does not carry fibers from all the roots of the brachial plexus. D. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and contains fibers from C5, C6, and C7. It does not carry fibers from the C8 or T1 roots, and therefore, does not have contributions from all the roots of the brachial plexus.

questions.text: A 53 y/o man with a history of depression presents to the ER with having cut deeply into the flexor surface of his wrist at the level of the carpal tunnel after he had fight with his wife. he has no sensation on the palmar or dorsal aspects of the distal parts of his middle and index fingers and half of his ring finger. Which of the following has been compromised?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Median nerve supplies in lateral 3 and a half fingers on palmar aspect and distal phalanx of lateral 3 and a half fingers on dorsal aspect.

questions.text: A 10 years old boy is brought to the emergency department because he is no longer able to fully extend the fingers of his right hand. he had suffered a right fibula fracture in a road accident 2 weeks before and was given a pair of crutches to use while his leg recovered. He lost that set of crutches and therefore he has been using his taller friend's crutches. which have been putting a lot of pressure on his axilla. On physical exam he is found to have a wrist drop and decreased sensation over his posterior forearm and dorsal hand. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the patients symptoms –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Radial nerve is compressed in Axilla due to pressure by longer crutches and patient has developed wrist drop.

questions.text: The nerve that supplies the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked structure is levator scapulae muscle which is supplied by dorsal scapular nerve [arises from C5 root]. Option B-Suprascapular nerve supplies supraspinatus and infraspinatus. Option C-Dorsal rami of C1 supplies muscles of back. Option D-Subscapular nerve supplies subscapularis.

questions.text: Which part of brachial plexus does not give any branch?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Roots gives rise to dorsal scapular nerve and long thoracic nerve. Option B-upper Trunk gives rise to suprascapular nerve and nerve to subclavius. Option C-Cords gives rise to numerous branches. Option D-No branch arises from Division.
